repnme.cdata!:
India - Hyderabad Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Achievement of development objectives of
            the Hyderabad Water Supply and Sanitation Project at closing
            was satisfactory. Implementation was also rated as
            satisfactory. The Project supported major improvements but
            there is a considerable way to go before Hyderabad
            Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWSSB) could
            be considered to be a modern water supply and sanitation
            (WSS) public utility.  Key lessons were learned in the
            following areas: institutional arrangements; ownership of
            assets; improved financial management; importance of
            training; drafting of the financial covenant; continuity of
            key bank staff; detailed design of component; links in the
            resettlement and rehabilitation program (RRP) to other
            government programs;  monitoring and evaluation of the RRP;
            downstream impacts of the dam; private sector participation;
            and inclusion of the summary actions table in mission aide-memoires.

India - Hyderabad Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

repnme.cdata!:
India - Hyderabad Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project : supervision mission no. 6 - September
            12 to 25, 1992

abstracts.cdata!:
This Aide Memoire reports that a World
            Bank mission visited Hyderabad, India 12-25 Sep-92 to
            supervise the Hyderabad Water Supply and Sanitation Project.
            The aide-memoire of the May-92 mission, in Section II
            thereof, contained a list of 20 actions recommended by or
            agreed with the mission; four of these actions were carried
            forward from a list of 10 such actions contained in the
            Jan-92 mission aide-memoire. These 20 actions and their
            current status are included in this aide memoire. Although
            the work of the mission has covered most aspects of the
            project, there has been a particular concentration on: (a)
            the Resettlement and Rehabilitation Program (RRP) for those
            people involuntarily displaced by the filling of the
            reservoir behind the Singur Dam, which is the source of the
            additional water to be supplied under the project; (b) the
            launching of the Low-Cost Sanitation Program (LCS) by the
            Hyderabad Metro Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HHWSSB);
            (c) the work of two engineering consulting firms who are
            assisting HHWSSB in the conduct of detailed studies and
            final design; and (d) the work of two financial management
            consulting firms who are assisting HMWSSB with the
            development and implementation of improved (and
            computerized) accounting and management information systems.
